Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "[ReleasePrep][2021.11.10]RI of dev into main" (#8875) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Opened pull request "Add domain & ignore www" (#8874) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Summary of the changes (in less than 80 characters):

* Add travis-ci.com abd travis-ci.org 
* Ignore `www,` for Uri host

Addresses https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/8868 & https://github.com/nuget/nugetgallery/issues/8801

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Trying to create sync DB connection synchronously before doing async" (#8870) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Addresses #8858 

All the changes are in https://github.com/NuGet/ServerCommon/pull/374

This just applies the API change to Gallery. `CreateDbConnection` method was updated to call sync version that tries to use cache and simply fails if any required information is not cached, then it falls back to the old behavior.

Some basic tests in dev indicate that the change reduces the amount of `Task.Result` calls in `CreateDbConnection` by a factor of more than 100x.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Bug]:  Use IAsyncServiceProvider extension methods instead of type casting ourselves" (#11339) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

Visual Studio Package Management UI

### Product Version

17.x

### Worked before?

N/A

### Impact

_No response_

### Repro Steps & Context

Use [`IAsyncServiceProvider` extension methods](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/microsoft.visualstudio.shell.iasyncserviceprovider?view=visualstudiosdk-2019#extension-methods) instead of type casting ourselves.

See https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/pull/4324/files#r737866598

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Show package vulnerabilities in the Visual Studio Package Manager UI" (#11054) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
**Feature Summary**

When a vulnerability in a NuGet package is discovered, surface an indicator of the vulnerability in the Package Manager UI to alert developers and help them take the appropriate action.

**Problem**

Vulnerabilities in packages can be leveraged by malicious actors to do harm to developers and their users. At the time of writing this, there are 113 NuGet advisories in the [GitHub Advisory Database](https://github.com/advisories?query=ecosystem%3Anuget). While package vulnerabilities can be found on NuGet.org and with the dotnet list command, most developer interactions with NuGet occur in the Visual Studio package manager UI where no vulnerability information is currently available.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Bug]: Visual Studio 2019 16.11.5 Enterprise advices me to update nuget package to version that is incompatible with my project TFM" (#11372) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

Visual Studio Package Management UI

### Product Version

dotnet sdk version: 6.0.100, msbuild version: 4.8.3752.0

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Repro Steps & Context

I have an ASP Core project that targets **.net5.0** TFM. I reference several **EntityFramework** nuget packages (**Microsoft.EntityFrameworkCore.*** and **Microsoft.AspNetCore.***) that are currently at version **5.0.12**. It is the latest version that is compatible with **.net5.0** TFM. But Visual Studio 2019 16.11.5 Enterprise advices me to update nuget packages to version **6.0.0** that is incompatible with my project TFM (it is compatible only with **.net6.0** TFM).
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/44995181/141057099-504bb466-6d0e-4d4a-9552-369bdecf0f42.png)

P. S. I also have Visual Studio 2022 17.0.0 Communuty Current istalled side-by-side.
### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Bug]: Package extraction sometimes fails with "file in use by another process"" (#11373) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

dotnet.exe, MSBuild.exe, NuGet.exe, Visual Studio Package Management UI, Visual Studio Package Manager Console

### Product Version

all

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Repro Steps & Context

In a recent case, it looks to be from trying to extract Microsoft.Packaging.SDKUtils.dll from the nupkg.  As far as the location in code, the access issue is hit in NuGet.Packaging.ZipArchiveExtensions.UpdateFileTimeFromEntry

1.	InstallFromSourceAsync() is called to extract a file
2.	NuGet.Packaging calls CopyFiles()
3.	Immediately after copying the file, it tries to update file attributes with UpdateFileTimeFromEntry()

The issue lies between 2 and 3.  I‚Äôve seen cases like Defender or other AV still inspecting files immediately when they are dropped, which could cause issues if you immediately try to access it again.  


### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Reopened issue "[Bug]: Cannot get INuGetProjectService from the service broker in Visual Studio 17" (#11367) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

MSBuild.exe

### Product Version

Visual Studio 17.0.0

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

I'm unable to use this version

### Repro Steps & Context

An exception is thrown in Visual Studio ~~2017~~ 2022 when trying to get an `INuGetProjectService` from the Visual Studio service broker. This code:
```cs
var serviceBrokerContainer = await ServiceProvider.GetGlobalServiceAsync<SVsBrokeredServiceContainer, IBrokeredServiceContainer>();
var serviceBroker = serviceBrokerContainer.GetFullAccessServiceBroker();

// This next line throws the exception.
var projectService = await serviceBroker.GetProxyAsync<INuGetProjectService>(NuGetServices.NuGetProjectServiceV1);
```
Throws this error in Visual Studio 17.0.0:
> Activating the "Microsoft.VisualStudio.NuGet.NuGetProjectService (1.0)" service failed.
> Unable to cast object of type 'NuGet.VisualStudio.Implementation.Extensibility.NuGetProjectService' to type 'NuGet.VisualStudio.Contracts.INuGetProjectService'.

The package references I'm using are:
```xml
<PackageReference Include="Microsoft.VisualStudio.SDK">
  <Version>17.0.31902.203</Version>
</PackageReference>
<PackageReference Include="NuGet.Protocol">
  <Version>6.0.0</Version>
</PackageReference>
<PackageReference Include="NuGet.VisualStudio">
  <Version>6.0.0</Version>
</PackageReference>
<PackageReference Include="NuGet.VisualStudio.Contracts">
  <Version>6.0.0</Version>
</PackageReference>
```

I'm also seeing a warning about the version of `Microsoft.ServiceHub.Framework` not being found. Could this be related? It seems like the `NuGetProjectService` returned from the service broker is implementing the `INuGetProjectService` interface from a different assembly to the one I am expecting.

Using this project file:
```xml
<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk">
  <PropertyGroup>
    <TargetFramework>net6.0</TargetFramework>
  </PropertyGroup>
  <ItemGroup>
    <PackageReference Include="NuGet.VisualStudio.Contracts" Version="6.0.0" />
  </ItemGroup>
</Project>
```
Restoring packages gives this warning:
> NU1603 NuGet.VisualStudio.Contracts 6.0.0 depends on Microsoft.ServiceHub.Framework (>= 2.7.327-preview) but Microsoft.ServiceHub.Framework 2.7.327-preview was not found. An approximate best match of Microsoft.ServiceHub.Framework 2.7.339 was resolved.

`Microsoft.ServiceHub.Framework 2.7.327-preview` is [not listed on NuGet](https://www.nuget.org/packages/Microsoft.ServiceHub.Framework/).

### Verbose Logs

_No response_
